subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today we're going to look at what animals
can teach us. With me is Miranda Alcott. She
is an intuitive animal communicator. She is
also the author of a chapter on Listening to
Water in an Anthology by Masaru Imoto called
The Healing Properties of Water. Welcome, Miranda.
Thank you. Thank you for inviting me.
It's a pleasure to be with you once again.
And the topic of learning, what we can learn
from animals, I have to think that the very
first thing for a person to be able to learn
from an animal is to believe that they can
because I think many people have the attitude
that we are so vastly superior, there's nothing that we can learn.
It is true. As a species, we have a bit of an
ego challenge with that. We consider ourselves
the top of the chain in everything. And it's
actually not accurate. There are citations
that actually function in a broader spectrum and
we are fast in the way we process information
in our brains. But for a long time, we've
assumed that bigger means that we have a better
brain for body size. However, we're finding out that's not actually true.
Well, of course, we have opposable thumbs. We make tools. We tell stories.
Yes, but then so do crows and so do chimps.
And there are a lot of beings that we share.
Bees I find absolutely fascinating. And perhaps
we'll get into that. But if we start looking
at who's around us, there's so much to learn.
And of course, many indigenous beings already
study what the animals have to teach us. But
on a daily basis, one of my favorite stories
is when I used to have a cat named Fred. And
when I was dating, Fred would, the man would
come to pick me up. So I'd let him in the door while he'd walk up the stairs and come
into the living room. And my cat would look
him over and either go, or would warm to the
person. And nine times out of 10, he would just blow the person off. And he's got to
be so irritating because he would know who
that person was before I did. So then I went
through a phase of when I would let the man
in, I would put the cat out. Because I wasn't
having any dating life at all. Because I knew
Fred was right on. But I learned the hard
way to follow what the signals Fred was giving
me because he knew energetically who I would
fit with.
And are you suggesting that the cat could read the moral character of the person? Or
more like the energy?
More like the energy because that cat knew who I was. We lived together. So from his
perspective, he was looking at, was it a fit
or not? Was it going to be a problem or not?
And so there are many couples that get young
couples usually that get an animal because
they want to see what they'd be like with a baby. So they bring in an animal. And that
animal creates all kinds of challenges for both of them to deal with. And they have to
deal with it. Many times, the people are not
ready to hear that they're not ready. But
many times, an animal will reflect back to us what it is we're working on.
So for instance, a very obvious thing is when
we have an angry person who's upset in their
lives and if you would ask them, they would
say they weren't angry. And they adopt a dog.
And the dog comes into the family. And that
dog becomes more aggressive. That dog becomes
very unhappy. That dog becomes on edge. And
the human is saying, Miranda, make him stop.
And it's really a matter of counseling with
the human and the animal because it's a matter
of addressing, by any chance, have you been
tense lately? Because this is really a living
barometer. This is not someone who came to
upset your life. This is someone who's letting
you know where you are in your life. Sometimes that's hard to hear.
So that's an example of you teaching the human, not the animal directly.
Right. Because as far as the animals teaching
us, they reflect back to us what our behaviors
are. If we pay attention, we can learn from the animals what they are teaching us.
Okay. But I am guessing that at a deeper level,
I'm going to call it a karmic level, animals
also come with something to teach us, wouldn't you say?
Absolutely. Sometimes they come knowing that
they're going to have a shorter life. Sometimes
they come knowing that the person they're working with, they're going to have a long
journey with to get them to learn self-reliance,
to get them to learn how to love, to get them
to learn how to trust. These are things that
animals teach us by their behaviors, by their
personalities. But I find most of the profound
teachings usually are verbalized toward the
end of that animal's life. When the human is accepting, this is really happening, my
animal is transitioning, and is there anything
he wants to tell me? And many times the animal
will say, what did you learn from me? And that's when the human has to come out with
what have they learned.
And again, this is where you are serving as a mediator, because without somebody who is
an intuitive communicator, such as yourself,
many people aren't going to hear their animal.
Well, and we'll have an exercise to help them
here as well. As a matter of fact, we might
as well just talk about that now, an exercise.
A really simple exercise, it's wonderful to
do, that everyone can do at home, is if your
animal is in another room and asleep or lying
down, you go into your living room, wherever,
and you sit and you close your eyes and quiet
yourself inside. Then picture your animal in
your mind and non-verbally call your animal
to you.
Now, the first time I did this exercise, I
just was trying to figure out how can people
do this? How will this happen? But the first
time I tried this exercise, I didn't have
all the hearing equipment, the hearing dog or
anything like that. And I had my very first
hearing dog in another room. So I sat down, closed my eyes, quieted, and inside I was
saying, radar, radar.
That's the name of...
That was the name of my dog.
Yeah.
And I sat there thinking, oh, this is going
to take forever. And then it hit me, Miranda,
how are you going to know that your dog is
here unless you open your eyes, your hearing
impaired? So I opened my eyes and here he was
checking his watch, sitting right in front
of me. He had been there for who knows how long. He'd come in from the other room.
Now, hold on. Checking his watch?
Which is an expression I have. It's an expression
I use because I could tell he'd been sitting
there for quite some time while I had been
wondering if he was going to come, wondering
if he was going to come, being hearing impaired. I couldn't hear him come in.
In other words, you're communicating telepathically.
Absolutely.
With your animal, but you didn't know that the animal had moved.
No, because of my hearing impairment. So I was thinking, I don't know if this exercise
is going to...
But you could have picked that up telepathically, too.
Well, I was a little impatient. I was a little impatient.
Okay.
But I have people that tell me they hear their
animals after they've transitioned. Sometimes
they will hear toenails on the floor. Sometimes
they'll feel them rush into them. And as a
matter of fact, I just had a wonderful Border
Collie, not Border Collie, but Rough Collie,
who transitioned recently, and he sends his human songs.
Now, what's interesting about that is she will put her iPod on shuffle, and she will
be quiet, and she'll say, I miss James. And the next thing that comes up is a song they
used to dance to, Happy Together. And it is so satisfying.
Well, we're going to do a whole other interview
on the question of the afterlife as it pertains
to humans, and animals, and pets, and so on.
But I'm very interested in the idea that the
animals, by their very nature, understand
certain spiritual principles that typically
elude most humans. For example, be here now.
Yes. Yeah.
They're very present. Animals are very present.
They watch our patterns. They watch our behaviors.
They know so much more about us than we know
about them. So someone will say, what is my
animal trying to tell me? And I'll say, be
quiet. And what did your animal just do? You
tell me, what did you just do? And what did
your animal just do? And they will say, well,
I have been impatient. I have been. And what
was your animal doing, lying on my feet? So
that animal was keeping you from moving? Well,
yeah. What happens when you don't move? I
have to slow down. You think?
Uh-huh.
Uh-huh.
So those are things that when people get into
looking in that way, it's not that far of
a reach. It really isn't. If anything, it's relaxing back into.
Uh-huh. Well, that sounds, again, it's like
energetic. The animals are picking up on our
energy. And if we're feeling, I use the word
frazzled, and the animal is, they're either
going to get that from us, or maybe they'll
find a way to help us get out of that space.
And also, when someone knocks on the door, or if you have a visitor come, watch what
your animal does. Because if your animal weaves
in between, there's a protection going on.
If your animal goes to the side and watches,
there's an uncertainty there. There's so much
going on that we just need to watch. But many
times, the lessons come when people are in
their dream state or a meditative state, and
then they will actually see this animal, and
they'll say to me, I got the sense, this is so strange, that he was trying to tell me
to slow down, or he was trying to tell me that
he doesn't like this person, or he doesn't,
and I don't know what to do with that, or I don't know how to be.
Uh-huh. Uh-huh.
Let me ask you this question. Humans are very
talented at sort of not being in the here
and now, and as a result of that, we have
fantasies. We can sometimes occupy a fantasy
world or we have a projection of the future.
We have an image of the past. We have a sense
of time as being much larger than the here and now moment. How is it for animals?
That's fascinating. Animals follow us of a tendency to follow us and watch what we do.
So remember that when we are imagining and moving forward or back or expanding, we're
visualizing that. That is one of the common languages that we share with most species.
So we're not saying anything, but we're visualizing
it. Just as we visualize, we may be going
on a walk and the dog is up and already at the door and we haven't moved. They see the
pictures. That's the common way. And as humans,
we picture just about everything that we do.
So looking at it from the standpoint of what
an animal has to teach us, it really comes
to are we willing to listen? Are we willing
to hear in more than very real physical way?
We have to be able to allow ourselves to expand
and receive in that expansion. So animals
are not, they are in the present. They teach
us to be in the present. But when we're in
our dream state, they too have other states that they're in that join us.
I see. In other words, they dream.
Well, we know we've seen them dream, but they
join us in what we are visualizing. They're
joining. It's the same thing really, Jeff,
when people say, I had this dream and it was
just so real. Well, those ones that are just
so real are very much joined by our animals.
We can see our animals usually in those in the lucid dreams. We can. So they are not
limited to this body.
So we're sharing many states of consciousness with animals in our lives.
And obviously, different species and different
varieties of animals have different personalities.
And therefore, I suppose the lessons that we
might learn from them are going to be somewhat
dependent on their personality.
Somewhat dependent on their personality, somewhat
dependent on their species, because we're
looking at a different culture than ours.
You have a tendency to say, if this animal is
really speaking, he has to speak in English
or he has to show me. That's so limited. That's
where our egos come in. We need to stop, get
off of that, settle down, and watch and learn about the other cultures.
I remember one time I was watching a nature film on television, and they were talking
about sea creatures communicating with each other. And they weren't even... Actually,
I shouldn't say that. They weren't addressing
the communication. They were saying, this
is how they spawn. This is what they do. And
in the background, this was a biology show.
In the background were tanks of live lobsters.
So the man's standing in front, and he's talking,
talking, talking. And behind him, I see over
on one side, I see a lobster do this. On the
other side, I see a lobster do that.
I'm thinking, oh my God, I'm seeing a language
here. And the man is talking right ahead.
Now, that was very exciting to me. I didn't know what to do with it. I put it into my
sleep state, and sure enough, here comes the
language. And I'm seeing it in my sleep state.
Yes, that is a whole other language. This is not just because the water is going this
way. So again, it's a matter of us opening up. What can we learn? That there's a lot
more going on than we thought.
In other words, like humans, animals use body language.
Yes.
And it's going to be very different for each species.
Yes. Different culture.
Yeah.
Yeah. You know, just as we know that dogs
looking each other in the eye, that's a challenge
to talk. That's fight. Come on out into the street. So it is best when we are hugging
our dogs to do that with the head, not that.
It's a mixed message. That is a mixed message.
It's like sort of wired into them.
Yes. It is. It's natural for them.
Well, one of the things that I believe dogs
are especially skilled at, certainly I think
more than cats, is the idea of unconditional
love for the humans in their lives.
Yeah. It's true. Cats demand a higher level of that expectation.
They want it from the human.
Yeah.
But dogs offer unconditional love, wouldn't you say?
Absolutely. Unconditional love. And you know,
we have a wonderful goal line that we live
on as humans. I want to do this in my life. I want to accomplish that. And we have the
soul line of how we are progressing and what we're
doing. And my feeling is that the intersection
of the soul line and the goal line is where
most domestic animals are, because they actually
bring us back to feeling love. They actually
remind us what we are here for and what we're
here to share and learn. Yeah. And animals have so much to give to us, but we have to
learn to listen. We must. Yeah.
Well, now we've talked about being quiet and
trying to communicate with the animal in a
quiet state. We've talked about what you might
pick up in a dream. We've talked about working
with a mediator such as yourself, an intuitive
communicator. I would think that the risk
in any of these for a skeptical person –
and surely we all have a skeptical side – is
how do I know it's not just projection on my
part, that I'm anthropomorphizing the animal?
For people that want to test that and that want
to hold back, they can. But I would suggest
that they then take the chance of going swimming
with animals, of exercising with animals,
and watching if they will allow the animal to guide them. The animal will take them to
a different venue. Just yesterday, a woman
was telling me about how she was walking her
dog on the sidewalk, and her dog all of a sudden had never had this behavior, quickly
pulled her into the street. And she was extremely
worried because there were cars going by.
But as the animal had pulled her into the street, here came a man up on the sidewalk,
and this dog was pulling her, pulling her
away. And so she'd never seen her dog act this
way. But she followed that lead, and as he
started to talk, he said, I lost my dog, and
that's a nice dog. And her whole feeling, she got it secondarily to her animal, and
she said, yes, I have to walk my dog really
fast because he needs exercise. If we listen,
it's there. We have so many stories of dolphins,
all kinds of sedations, sedations moving
us in different directions, leading us to things that we need to know.
Well, there are examples of sedations, dolphins
in particular, saving the lives of humans.
And I know the Maori people in New Zealand,
they call themselves the people of the dolphin.
I believe they believe that the dolphins brought them to New Zealand.
Yes, Maori are wonderful. Yes, they really understand so much about what's going on.
Yes, indeed they do. I did some wonderful interviews with a New Zealand naturalist,
Wade Doak, had very, very extensive human-animal
interactions with the dolphins, and he would
always go to the Maori shaman when he needed to interpret what was being said.
Yeah, I had the wonderful joy of working with
some Maori, the Maori chief, in that situation.
And they handed me a wonderful stone, and I did not know what it was, but I held it.
And what I saw and where I was taken was with
a huge whale, way deep down deep to the point
where I was scared because I couldn't see anything. It was cold and it was dark. But
I could feel this wonderful whale. I just trusted and was with this whale. So when I
came out, it was a meeting and many of the
tribe were there. And when I came out, I said,
I don't know what this is, but this is where
I went. And he said, Miranda, that is a whale
ear bone you are holding, which was very sweet.
But that trust of that and the Maori hold
that so dear. They do not take animal life for granted.
Well, you started by saying that indigenous people seem to understand that they have a
lot to learn from animals, something that we in this so-called civilized world seem
to have lost.
There are animals that are constantly trying
to tell us that our planet is at danger. There
are many species that have left the Earth because we are too late in recognizing what
we need to do. There's another example of
listening to animals. We can say, well, what
do we need this species for? But the danger
signals are all there. It's already happening.
It's already happening.
Well, we're living in the middle of one of the largest mass extinctions in geological
history.
We are. And it is very serious. It is very serious.
And it's caused by our species.
Yes, it is. We own that one completely. And
for many years, I would hear the animals say
to me, we have to do something. You have to tell your people, Miranda. You have to tell
your people. What's interesting about my working
with the animals is I was gifted and told
that I would be working with more humans if I worked with their animals. And it's true.
The animals don't really have the issues. We do. And so someone can come in and say,
you tell him and you tell him about the animal.
And what happens is the animal is saying,
you know, help her out. She doesn't have a clue. You know? And so it's a matter of how
do we integrate, you know? And if you were
in his position, what would you do? How would
you get your attention? And how would you do this? It's just a little bit of weaving.
But then people come back to me and say, I
saw him do this. I saw him do that. I followed
him and he took me. So it can happen. We just have to allow it.
Well, what is it about indigenous people that makes them more open to this?
In the beginning, their beginning beliefs were not as distracted as ours have been.
The more modernized we become, the more we turn off our intuitive selves. So we're not
listening to our intuition. Indigenous people
pride themselves on their intuition. Now,
depending on where you are now, most indigenous
people are very challenged right now because
of what we've done with the planet. So even though they have those core, that core in
them, they may not be as in touch with it as
they used to be. But what's also interesting
is there's a whole movement of people that are
non-indigenous. And there are some indigenous
teachers that point to those people and say,
those people are more indigenous than some
of us. Because that rebirthing and coming back around in that circle of learning is
occurring again. And it needs to be massively occurring.
I wonder if part of the problem is that many
humans, we don't even think of ourselves as
animals anymore. And we are. We're mammals.
We are. We are animals.
We are just one species. We think that because
we populate all over, that another species
has to prove to us that they are intelligent.
And it's interesting because there isn't
really a great definition of intelligence,
which is fascinating to me, because all you're
doing is comparing us against everyone else.
You're saying they have to prove this to us
before we'll...
Well, you're touching upon another topic that
I hope to do a separate interview on, the
distinction between human and animal. Because
I know we have so much in common, but there
are differences.
Definitely, there are differences. Big differences, yeah.
So that'll be a topic for another time.
I look forward to that.
Uh-huh.
I look forward to that.
But we have just a couple of minutes left. And is there a final thought that you might
have for people who really sense that their animal is trying to teach them something?
Yeah.
Is there anything further that they might do to open up to that?
You know, one of the things that's simple
that people think about and they don't follow
through with, and that is when they're leaving
their house, because they have animals in
their home, when they're leaving their homes
to turn to the animal and say out loud, because
we picture when we're saying and we're thinking
it, I'm going to be gone for a few hours.
I'll be back before dark, and I need you to look after the house. I need you to protect
the house. And then you leave. You picture yourself coming back before dark as you're
leaving. Picture that. Now you come home, and you open the door, and the animals are
excited to see you, but you don't actually
pet them or acknowledge until you look around
the house and see, the house is safe. Good job. Now everybody's excited, and they're
going off. Pat, pat, pat. Giving them a timeframe
gives them security, because being in a home,
they are totally dependent on us. So it's a simple way to share your lives with your
animals in such a way, and they're sharing
their lives with their humans, that everyone
can feel more grounded. There's a lot of profundity in there, because
what you're saying is just by speaking, they
may not be able to interpret our words, but
they see the pictures in our mind. So we can speak to our animals.
You can. You can speak to your animals. And
you'd be surprised how many domestic animals
actually know sentences and words. They're exposed to us and exposed to us.
Well, Miranda Alcott, once again, this has
been an enlightening time. Thank you so much
for being with me. Oh, you're so welcome. I'm excited. Thank
you for asking. My pleasure. And thank you for being with us.
Thank you.
Thank you.
